data:
Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is a defect in carbohydrate metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme aldolase B (in the liver, kidney cortex, and small intestine). This means patients with HFI cannot break down fructose. Ingestion can lead to severe metabolic decompensation. HFI is treated by eliminating all sucrose, fructose, and sorbitol from diet and medications.
Signs and symptoms of illness include: 
- nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, pallor, lethargy, metabolic acidosis, coma and seizures

Laboratory findings: 
- Rapid decrease of serum phosphate followed by rapid decrease of blood glucose, increase of urate and magnesium, increase of liver enzymes

If untreated chronic manifestations include failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, jaundice, bleeding tendency, ascites, proximal renal tubulopathy
Discontinue all fructose, sucrose and sorbitol from diet, oral medications and IV infusions.  No juices, fruits or vegetables. May continue normal home diet

This patient cannot have any fructose, sorbital or sucrose. These sugars are found in fruits, vegetables, honey, table sugar, sugar alcohol, many syrups, processed foods, beverages and medications. Infant formula's often contain fructose and may be contraindicated. Please contact the Biochemical Genetics team if you suspect there is fructose in any of the products provided
